sections.summary: The Quran was revealed on a **Blessed Night** to serve as a warning and as a means to distinguish every wise command. Allah is established as the **Lord of the heavens and the earth**, the sole deity who gives life and causes death, manifesting His mercy through this **Enlightening Scripture**.

Disbelievers who play in doubt are warned of a Day when the sky will produce a **visible smoke** that envelops mankind as a painful punishment. Although they may plead for the **torment** to be lifted by professing belief, it is noted they will revert to their previous state, leading to divine **vengeance** during the Great Assault.

sections.theme: The Narrative of Moses and Pharaoh
sections.summary: Pharaoh and his people were tested when a **noble messenger** arrived, demanding the release of Allah’s servants and asserting his clear authority [403–404]. Despite their arrogance, the Children of Israel were delivered across the sea while the **transgressing tyrant** and his army were drowned, leaving behind their gardens and splendid buildings.

Rejecters of the **resurrection** claim there is nothing beyond the first death, yet they are reminded of the annihilation of the people of Tubba and other **evildoers**. The heavens and earth were created for a **specific purpose** rather than play, and all humanity will meet at the appointed **Day of Sorting Out** [404–405].

The **Tree of Bitterness** is identified as the food of the sinner, behaving like molten lead that boils within the belly. Sinners will be dragged into the midst of Hell to taste the suffering of the **Inferno** as a consequence for the power and nobility they once claimed in the worldly life.

The **righteous** are promised a secure place amidst gardens and springs, adorned in silk and brocade and wed to lovely companions. They will enjoy peace and security, spared from the **torment of Hell** and protected from death beyond the first, signifying the **supreme salvation** granted by their Lord.
